rComments: Not a great prof, I really wanted to like his class but he honestly made it unbearable. His assignments were seemingly easy, but he grades so hard. His exam was absolutely terrible, literally info we discussed in class for two minutes were long answer questions. He did not prepare us at all for his exam, it was a complete joke. THE hardest exam.
Professeur très exigent et conservateur dans ses exigences et ses examens. Trop de charge de travail.

Very good professor. He enjoys what he teaches and that shows in his enthusiasm. Taking detailed notes is important as most of the material is given verbally. Accessible outside class and is accommodating to student needs. Most marks come from reports and papers which he grades tough, but provides very good feedback.
Not accessible outside class. Tough grader.

This professor is very excited to share his knowledge, especially on Canadian history and will attempt to crack a few jokes during classes. He sometimes talks a little fast and his grading is a little tough but he gives great feedback to better your work.

Professor Lozier is interesting and knowledgable about the subject, especially the middle portion of the content. The paper we wrote was a new style for me, but anyone majoring in History will need to know the style. He gives you two chances for feedback before handing in the final draft. Highly, highly recommend.
Interesting

Professor Lozier is one of the best professors I have ever had! In AHL4900 we worked close with the Canadian Museum of Science and Technology and were doing our own research. This was not an easy task but Lozier made it super fun and really put his heart into the class. It was one of the best seminars I have ever taken. Fully recommend!

Loved him! He loves what he teaches. A lot of work to do and a 15 pages essay but it's easy to get a good grade with it. Important to go to class since he doesnt post anything on brightspace! the midterm is easy but the final is a lot of big questions and like simple spaced 1 and 2 pages of answer which we didnt know until the final which sucked

Overall, Lozier makes history and Canadian studies highly interesting. The course material, once synthesized makes perfect sense and are easy to touch upon during his exams (as long as you take notes!) His expectations are clear, and even if they are not, he is very responsive. Overall, he respects and cares about his students! Would take again!

He's a good and caring guy who loves history and loves teaching it. If you don't go to class, you won't pass and his exams are pretty specific so you need to study. He's a fair marker and his lecture can get dry sometimes, but overall he's a good prof.

He is very passionate about what he's teaching, always animated and gives clear explanations. If you study hard, the finals are straightforward -- take good notes and do your readings, and you'll do great.

He's a very entertaining and engaging lecturer, but that's where it ends. He doesn't use blackboard, he often missed office hours, he'd give his expectations for an assignment after we handed it in, and he'd often tell us to know about certain things (PM Borden, PM Bennett, Group of 7) that weren't on the exam. Easy grader, and nice though.

Both his midterm and final exam were very hard, loaded with complicated and/or trick questions. I am particularly disappointed with his final, which was chock full of obscure content we barely covered. He told us to "be familiar with the major building blocks of Canada," but none of which were present on his final. Very disappointed!

Super friendly, energetic, and passionate prof. Although his lectures are very very difficult to take notes from and is folloed up with very tricky exams and assignments. He answers emails pretty fast though. Overall it was a pretty challenging and boring class. Unless it is a mandatory, I would not recommend.

Nice guy with a good sense of humour, he is very approachable, caring, answers emails, and answers any questions. But he doesn't use Blackboard, and his lectures are basically a narration over powerpoint slideshows of pictures. The rest is up to you, and with a dense textbook you are essentially required to memorize, I personally struggled.
teacherRatingTags: ['Get ready to read', 'Accessible outside class', 'Gives good feedback']

rComments: Despite it being a trial run for a class idea, is as clear as he possibly can be with expectations. Understands when things come up (Like the internet being cut again, ty construction :P ) but doesn't let you completely skip off and do nothing either.
Really engaging and interesting, enjoy all the classes I take with him!

His lectures are extremely long, all he does is read his slides. He doesn't put anything on blackboard, and he doesn't respond to his emails. I think he's still stuck in 1784 when no technology was available. On top of that, he is a very hard grader. Overall 4 out of 10.
Very clear lecturer, pretty funny guy. Sometimes brings historical objects to demonstrate (furs, coins, beads...). He is a fair grader and is clear in his expectations.
Il faut absolument assister aux cours. Il amene souvent des objets historiques en classe et est clair dans ses explications.

Professor Lozier is fantastic. He is a bit heavy on the writing, but his lectures are wonderful, animated, and involved. The assignments are interesting and out of the ordinary for most University work. Heavily recommended. Speaks fluent English and French without a hint of an accent. Very generous marker.
